abstract.text: An object that manages the timing and progress of animations in the user interface.

inlineContent.text: also lets you link together multiple animations so that when one animation ends another one starts. It does not provide any drawing support for animation and does not directly deal with views, targets, or actions.
For simple tasks requiring a timing mechanism, consider using

objects have several characteristics, including duration, frame rate, and animation curve, which describes the relative speed of the animation over its course. You can set progress marks in an animation, each of which specifies a percentage of the animation completed; when an animation reaches a progress mark, it notifies its delegate and posts a notification to any observers. Animations execute in one of three blocking modes: blocking, non-blocking on the main thread, and non-blocking on a separate thread. The non-blocking modes permit the handling of user events while the animation is running.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An object that manages the timing and progress of animations in the user interface.
These constants indicate the blocking mode of an
object when it is running.
These constants describe the curve of an animation—that is, the relative speed of an animation from start to finish.
The animation progress, as a floating-point number between
and
Adds the progress mark to the receiver.
The blocking mode of the animation.
The timing curve for the animation.
Clears linkage to another animation that causes the receiver to start.
Clears linkage to another animation that causes the receiver to stop.
The current progress of the animation.
The current value of the animation effect, based on the current progress
The animation delegate.
The duration of the animation, in seconds.
The number of frame updates per second to generate for the animation.
Returns an
object initialized with the specified duration and animation-curve values.
A Boolean value indicating whether the animation is in progress.
Posted when the current progress of a running animation reaches one of its progress marks.
An array of floating-point numbers representing current progress marks.
Removes progress mark from the receiver.
An array of strings representing the run loop modes in which the animation can run.
Starts the animation represented by the receiver.
Starts running the animation represented by the receiver when another animation reaches a specific progress mark.
Stops the animation represented by the receiver.
Stops running the animation represented by the receiver when another animation reaches a specific progress mark.
A set of optional methods implemented by delegates of
objects.
Requests a custom curve value for the current progress value.
An animation of an app’s views, limited to changes in frame location and size, and to fade-in and fade-out effects.
This constant is returned in the userInfo dictionary of the
notification.
A timer that fires after a certain time interval has elapsed, sending a specified message to a target object.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
